q1.value: Study 3: Expanding the types of short-term goals people might desire, crave, feel urges or temptations to engage in

q2.value: Jennifer Veilleux, Kayla Skinner, Danielle Baker, Kaitlyn Chamberlain

q3.value: This study is intended to replicate and extend Study 2, to understand the distinctions between desire, craving, urge and temptation.  In the prior study, we examined three short-term goals (food, sex, alcohol) and long-term goals via vignette. In this study we focus on short term goals, but expand the types of goals beyond the three from the prior study to include additional reward short-term goals (buying things, checking your phone for notifications) as well as other types of motivations that people sometimes feel compelled to do (e.g., contact an ex, criticize someone, punch someone, avoid negative emotion, lie around and do nothing).  We also focus on the participant’s own self rather than characters in the vignette, and we expand the questions asked to begin to understand the distinctions between the four terms on a sense of conflict and use of terms to justify actions.

q4.value:
For the clear reward goals (food, sex, alcohol, shopping, phone) we expect craving to be associated with greater strength of wanting, higher need, greater liklihood of action, and greater physical sensations compared to the other three terms.  We likewise expect craving and urge to be less pleasant than desire or temptation for these goals.  These are replicating and extending results from Study 2.  

We do not have directional predictions for the other five goal types, though we expect urge and temptation to differ from craving and desire for these goals.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This is a between-subjects design with 1 factor (term: desire, craving, urge, and temptation).  There are also 10 different desires which are within-subject….it is unclear on the front end if these will be able to be grouped (which would then result in a 4 x X) mixed design, where X would be the number of groups.  This grouping is currently unclear.

q9.value: People will be randomized to one of the four desire terms using the Randomizer in the Study Flow within Qualtrics.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will collect data via both Prolific and a university subject pool. Prolific participants will be paid $1.50 for a 10 minute study (consistent with the $9/hr in our IRB). Subject pool participants will credited ¼ credit (used for studies 15 min or less).  All participants will be retained who report it is their first time to complete the study, who indicate we can keep their data and do not report in-study inattentiveness.

q13.value: The target sample size is 400.  We plan to get 200 participants from Prolific and the other 200 from the subject pool

q14.value: We wish to have about 100 participants per group, consistent with the prior study.

q15.value: We can collect 200 participants via Prolific.  Subject pool participation will go until we reach 200 or the end of the semester, whichever happens first.

question.value: We will manipulate the desire term the participant sees—desire, craving, urge or temptation.  All scenarios each participant reads will describe the want something using this term.

We will measure strength of wanting, the degree to which a person says they “need” the action or object, pleasantness of the wanting, how physical the wanting feels, and how likely they would be to engage in the action (to pursue the short-term goals).  We will also ask their degree of conflict over engaging in the action, and to what degree their actions were justified.  All of these variables will be measured on a 0 (not at all) to 6 (extremely) Likert-type scale. Finally, we will ask whether what is being sought is (a) the object or action itself, (b) the feeling during the activity or (c) the feeling after the activity.
We will use ANOVA to compare the four terms on each of the eight outcome variables.  We will use Bonferroni-corrected post-hoc tests to follow up significant ANOVAs.

q21.value: Due to the number of tests conducted, we will use a p < .01 criteria for determining significance for both ANOVAs and for corrected post-hoc tests.

q24.value: We may combine some of the goals to look at how the ten included goals are potentially grouped together, but this will be exploratory.

attributes.title: Mental health project for Wuhan coronavirus outbreak
attributes.description: This is an open-ended project. We aim to investigate the social-psychological factors that may affect people living in Wuhan, where China's coronavirus outbreak began. By a two-wave longitudinal design, we plan to recruit Wuhan participants from the internet. The project will collect data using the doctor-patient trust scale, risk perception scale, and consumer purchase items. The results will contribute to public health and epidemiological research.

summary.value: This is an open-ended project. We aim to investigate the social-psychological factors that may affect people living in Wuhan, where China's coronavirus outbreak began. By a two-wave longitudinal design, we plan to recruit Wuhan participants from the internet. The project will collect data using the doctor-patient trust scale, risk perception scale, and consumer purchase items. The results will contribute to public health and epidemiological research.

By a two-wave longitudinal design, we plan to recruit Wuhan participants from the internet. The project will collect data using the doctor-patient trust scale, risk perception scale, and consumer purchase items. The results will contribute to public health and epidemiological research.

attributes.title: Systematic review of participatory wellbeing frameworks

q1.value: What matters to people throughout the world? A systematic review of participatory wellbeing frameworks

q2.value: Kate Sollis, Nicholas Biddle, Mandy Yap

q3.value:
This review seeks to collate the various studies throughout the world that have developed participatory wellbeing frameworks. The key purpose is to produce a list of frameworks that have been developed, outlining the country, study population, method, and wellbeing dimensions. This will help researchers in the field understand where these frameworks have been developed. It will also help researchers/practitioners who are working in these areas to more easily identify relevant studies that they can draw on for their research/work.

A secondary purpose is to code the wellbeing dimensions to a ‘global list’ that can be used to analyse how wellbeing is conceptualised differently throughout the world.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The in-scope criteria for this study is as follows:
•	Studies must focus on conceptualising well-being, as opposed to ill-being or deprivation. This involves phrasing the study questions positively, such as “what does well-being mean to you?”, or “what does a good life mean to you?”.
•	The question framing must be global, that is, ask individuals about their lives generally. Studies that individuals about particular facets of their life (e.g. in education, as a mother) are not in-scope.
•	Studies must include data collection methods that interact directly with the in-scope population, such as interviews, focus groups or surveys. Studies that also consult with other populations (e.g. parents, bureaucrats), on top of the target population, are also considered in-scope.
•	A framework, including a list of dimensions and/or indicators must be clearly specified.
•	Data collection methods must include at least one open-ended question regarding what wellbeing means to the participants. This thus excludes studies that purely ask participants to rank wellbeing areas according to a pre-defined list.
•	Studies that seek to validate a pre-defined list through social research are in-scope, but only if the final wellbeing framework differs to that of the original list.

Studies will not be assessed with any quality markers, and both published and grey literature is in-scope. Only studies that have been published since 1st January 2000 are in scope.

The review will search seven databases to retrieve relevant studies that develop a participatory wellbeing framework. Google (first 100 results) will also be searched to find any additional studies in either the published or grey literature. All reference lists will be scanned to identify any additional studies. Finally, key researchers in the field will be contacted to ascertain whether any studies are missing, and other studies known to the authors will also be included.

The search databases that will be used are ASSIA, PubMed, PsycInfo, Social Sciences Citation Index, IBSS and Sociological Abstracts. These databases were chosen for their relevance to the research subject, and to cover the various disciplines that are in-scope (i.e. social sciences, psychology and health).

The following search terms will be used:
Wellbeing: “quality of life” OR “well-being” OR wellbeing OR 
                     HRQOL OR capability OR capabilities OR "good life"
Framework: framework AND (dimension OR indicator OR domain OR theme)
Participatory: "participatory method" OR "participatory technique" OR  
                          "participatory research" OR "participatory framework" OR  
                          "participatory approach" OR "participatory process" OR 
                          "participatory wellbeing" OR "participatory well-being" OR  
                          "participatory assessment" OR “participatory mechanism OR  
                          "participatory study" OR “participatory studies” OR
                          "participatory exercise" OR "participatory activity" OR “participatory 
                           activities” OR "participatory evaluation" OR "self-perceive" OR 
                           "self perceive" OR "self-rate" OR "self rate" OR “self assess” OR 
                           “self-assess” OR “self generate” OR self-generate” OR person 
                           generate” OR person-generate”

Two authors will screen the title/abstract to determine possible eligible studies, and two authors will then screen the full-text. Any conflicts will be resolved by a third author.

The data will be extracted by two authors as a quality assurance process, with the collected data being: basic publication information (title, author, journal etc.), country, population group, method, the level of participation in study, sample size, theoretical basis for study, list of wellbeing dimensions, and list of wellbeing indicators (if applicable).

The screening and data extraction processes will be conducted through the Covidence Systematic Review platform.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Data will be collected by reviewing the included studies. This will be conducted by two authors, who will each extract the information on basic publication information (title, author, journal etc.), country, population group and any subgroups, method, level of participation in study, method, sample size, theoretical basis for study, list of dimensions, and list of indicators (if applicable).

q13.value: The number of in-scope studies is not yet known. This will be determined following the full-text screening.

question.value:
The extracted data of interest in this systematic review are:
- Countries where the frameworks have been developed
- The different population groups, and any subgroups
- The various methodologies applied
- The theoretical basis for the study
- The list of dimensions and/or indicators
Statistical models will not be used in this study. The analysis will be comprised of basic summary statistics.

q24.value:
The analysis of the countries, population groups, methods, samples sizes, and theoretical bases for study will be expressed through some simple summary statistics.

To analyse the lists of dimensions (or indicators), the dimensions/indicators will be coded to a ‘global’ list. This list will initially be developed by KS, through a data-driven process. 

Once the ‘global’ list has been established, KS and MY will independently code the extracted wellbeing dimensions/indicators to the global list. If there are any disagreements, NB will assess and determine the most appropriate global dimension.

Once this process is complete, some basic summary statistics of the wellbeing dimensions/indicators can be reported on.

This will help researchers in the field understand where these frameworks have been developed. It will also help researchers/practitioners who are working in these areas to more easily identify relevant studies that they can draw on for their research/work.

A secondary purpose is to code the wellbeing dimensions to a ‘global list’ that can be used to analyse how wellbeing is conceptualised differently throughout the world.

attributes.title: The Perception of Cognitive Triad According to Attachment Styles with Pets and Parents
attributes.description: Animal-Assisted Therapy (AAT) is a supportive approach to the improvement of mental health using the healing side of the interaction between humans and animals in the treatment of individuals with chronic disorders that cause a negative impact on their quality of life. As a result of the cooperation of the multidisciplinary team, important developments can be achieved on the psychological, emotional, social and physical well-being of the patients. In Turkey, in the absence of this special method of therapy it is not applied itself as a science-based technical expertise; however, it is included as a short-term application in the well-structured intervention processes of patients. For this reason, it is thought that the number of studies which can offer theoretical support to AAT should be increased. The purpose of this study is to examine how attachment styles to pets and parents are reflected in the cognitive triad for individuals through various variables. In this context, the historical development of AAT, its contributions to the field and its limitations in practice will be discussed in the light of the relevant literature; how independent variables are determinate and differentiated in predicting cognitive triad. In this context the historical development of this specific therapy method, its contributions and limitations will be discussed.

q1.value: The Perception of Cognitive Triad According to Attachment Styles with Pets and Parents

q3.value: Animal-Assisted Therapy (AAT) is a supportive approach to the improvement of mental health using the healing side of the interaction between humans and animals in the treatment of individuals with chronic disorders that cause a negative impact on their quality of life. Thanks to the cooperation of the multidisciplinary coworkers cricial improvements can be achieved on the psychological, emotional, social and physical well-being of the patients. In Turkey because of the absence of aforementioned intervention method, it is not applied in itself as a pyschotherapeutic method. It is just included as a short-term application in the well-structured intervention processes of patients in stead of whole intervention. For this reason, it is thought that the number of studies which might offer theoretical support to AAT should be increased.  It is thought that this study will be one of the evidence-based research on this issue. The purpose of this study will examine how attachment styles to pets and parents are reflected in the cognitive triads for individuals through various variables. In this context, the historical development of AAT, its contributions to the intervention practices and its limitations in terms of patients will be discussed in the light of the relevant literature. Additionally, how independent variables (attachment styles to pets and parents) are differentiated in predicting cognitive triad will try to be illustrated.

q4.value:
Research Questions:
1. Are the relationships between individuals' attachment styles to their pets and parents and the basic cognitions which is called cognitive triad meaningful?
2. Do scores of cognitive triad differ according to the attachment styles of individuals to their pets and parents?
3. Do individuals' perceptions on self, outer world, and future significantly predict on their attachment sytles to pets and parents, some defined demographic features, and conditions of pets?

Hypotheses:
1. Individuals who are securely attached to their pets and parents are expected to be the group with the highest score (positive-triad) from the Turkish Version of Cognitive Triad Inventor for Adults. Additionally, it is expected that the scores that individuals who are securely attached to their pets and insecurely attached to their parents will get from the Turkish Version of Cognitive Triad Inventory for Adults will be higher than the scores that individuals who are insecurely attached to both their pets and parents will get from the Turkish Version of Cognitive Triad Inventory for Adults. Finally, individuals who are insecurely attached to their pets and parent are expected to be the group with the lowest score (negative-triad) from the Turkish Version of Cognitive Triad Inventory for Adults.

2. Individuals who are securely attached to the pets will receive from the Turkish Version of Cognitive Triad Inventory for Adults will be higher than the scores that individuals who are insecurely attached to their pet will receive from the Turkish Version of Cognitive Triad Inventory for Adults. It is expected that the scores that individuals who are securely attached to their parents will receive from the Turkish Version of Cognitive Triad Inventory for Adults will be higher than the scores that individuals who are insecurely attached to their parents will receive from the Turkish Version of Cognitive Triad Inventory for Adults. It is also estimated that the positive triad will be mainly predicted to the attachment style of pets in stead of the attachment style of parents.

3. Individuals who are insequrely attached to their parents and raised in a family which have a pet when they are between 5 and 11, will have high positive cognitive triad compared with those who do not.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: It will be measured the relationship between the attachment styles of individuals to their pets and parents, and the cognitive triad. The participants who are over their 28 and have pet will be reached randomly. In the Informed Consent Form which was prepared by researcher, it was stated that the purpose of the research.  The answers will be kept confidential and used only for scientific purposes. The participation will be based on volunteering, and the approvals of the participants will be obtained. The scales will be given to participants via Qualtrics. IBM SPSS 22.0 version will be used to analyze the collected data. Percentage, mean, standard deviation, frequency, correlation analysis, two-way ANOVA and regression analyzes will be used. Data on incomplete scales will not be included in the analyzes.

q9.value: The participation to the study will be based on volunteering, and the approvals of the participants will be obtained.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value: The participation will be based on volunteering, and the approvals of the participants will be obtained. The scales will be given to participants via Qualtrics.

q13.value: The main sample of the study will consists of minimum 206 participants who are adult and have pet will be selected randomly. The interaction effect of the first independent variable based on the attachement style of pets (high secure attachment-low secure attachment) and the second independent variable based on the attachment style of parents (high secure attachment-low secure attachment) on the cognitive triad is df = 2 and the total number of groups are (2 × 2) n = 4.

q14.value: It is used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. The total number of participants required for the possibility of rejecting the H0 hypothesis correctly by 95% was determined as minimum 206 by G*Power analysis.

question.value:
1. The Turkish Version of Lexington Attachment to Pets Scale consists of a 4 Likert-type and 23-item. It has a 3-factor; the connection to the pet (My pet understands when I feel bad.), assuming the friendship of pet equal to people (My pet is more valuable to me than any friend), and lastly assuming the rights of animals equal to people (Pets, like all family members, have the same rights and privileges.). General attachment factor is represented by items 10, 11, 12, 13, 15, 17, 18, 19, 21, 22 and 23; human replacement factor is represented by items 1, 2, 4, 5, 6, 7 and 9; animal rights factor is represented by items 3, 8, 14, 16 and 20. The reliability of the scale was tested with the Cronbach Alpha coefficient. There was evidence of the reliability of the Turkish form in the factors of total (.91), human replacement (.78), animal rights (.70) and general attachment (.86). The increase in the total score obtained from the scale indicates an increase in the level of attachment to the animal. 

2. Three Dimensional Attachment Styles Scale was developed by Erzen (2015) aims to measure secure, avoided and anxious attachment styles. The scale consists of 18 items evaluated in the Likert-type 5. .72 for content validity were calculated. According to exploratory factor analysis, secure attachment factor is represented by items 4, 7, 10, 13, 16 (I get along well with my parents (mother, father or someone else taking care of me).), avoided attachment factor is represented by items 1, 3, 5, 9, 12, 15 (People who I know are not as valuable as me.), and anxious attachment factor is represented by items 2, 6, 8, 11, 14, 17 (I stay away from people because they can make me suffer). According to the factors of the scale, the internal consistency coefficient was found to be .69 for secure attachment style, .80 for avoided attachment style and .71 for anxious attachment style. Low scores from the scale indicate insecure attachment, and high scores indicate secure attachment to the parents.

3. Cognitive Triad Inventory is composed of items that measure both positive and negative cognitions of individuals. Self-perception factor is represented by items 6, 9, 11, 15, 16, 19, 26, 28, 32, 36 (I can do many things well), world perception factor is represented by items 5, 10, 13, 17, 21, 25, 29, 31, 33, 35 (The world is a very hostile place.), and future perception factor is represented by items 3, 8, 12, 18, 20, 23, 24, 27, 30, 34. (Nothing I expect from the future.). In the form, which is prepared in 7-point Likert type, one of the options is marked between "I disagree" (1 point) and "I fully agree" (7 points) for each item. While the items are scored, all of the positive items are reversed and the low scores from the scale reflect the positive cognitive triad, and the high scores reflect the negative cognitive triad. The Cronbach Alpha reliability coefficient for the whole scale was reported as .91, .85 for self-perception, .72 for world perception, and .87 for future perception.

IBM SPSS 22.0 version will be used to analyze the collected data. Percentage, mean, standard deviation, frequency, correlation analysis, 2X2 two-way ANOVA and regression tests and analyzes will be used. Data on incomplete scales will not included in the study.

q24.value: It is expected that certain demographic traits may be related to the styles of attachment to pets and parents. Therefore, it will looked for relationships between demographic variables (i.e. age, gender, income, and marital status) and the attachment styles to both pets and parents.

registration_responses.q1: The Perception of Cognitive Triad According to Attachment Styles with Pets and Parents
registration_responses.q3: Animal-Assisted Therapy (AAT) is a supportive approach to the improvement of mental health using the healing side of the interaction between humans and animals in the treatment of individuals with chronic disorders that cause a negative impact on their quality of life. Thanks to the cooperation of the multidisciplinary coworkers cricial improvements can be achieved on the psychological, emotional, social and physical well-being of the patients. In Turkey because of the absence of aforementioned intervention method, it is not applied in itself as a pyschotherapeutic method. It is just included as a short-term application in the well-structured intervention processes of patients in stead of whole intervention. For this reason, it is thought that the number of studies which might offer theoretical support to AAT should be increased.  It is thought that this study will be one of the evidence-based research on this issue. The purpose of this study will examine how attachment styles to pets and parents are reflected in the cognitive triads for individuals through various variables. In this context, the historical development of AAT, its contributions to the intervention practices and its limitations in terms of patients will be discussed in the light of the relevant literature. Additionally, how independent variables (attachment styles to pets and parents) are differentiated in predicting cognitive triad will try to be illustrated.
registration_responses.q4:
Research Questions:
1. Are the relationships between individuals' attachment styles to their pets and parents and the basic cognitions which is called cognitive triad meaningful?
2. Do scores of cognitive triad differ according to the attachment styles of individuals to their pets and parents?
3. Do individuals' perceptions on self, outer world, and future significantly predict on their attachment sytles to pets and parents, some defined demographic features, and conditions of pets?

Hypotheses:
1. Individuals who are securely attached to their pets and parents are expected to be the group with the highest score (positive-triad) from the Turkish Version of Cognitive Triad Inventor for Adults. Additionally, it is expected that the scores that individuals who are securely attached to their pets and insecurely attached to their parents will get from the Turkish Version of Cognitive Triad Inventory for Adults will be higher than the scores that individuals who are insecurely attached to both their pets and parents will get from the Turkish Version of Cognitive Triad Inventory for Adults. Finally, individuals who are insecurely attached to their pets and parent are expected to be the group with the lowest score (negative-triad) from the Turkish Version of Cognitive Triad Inventory for Adults.

2. Individuals who are securely attached to the pets will receive from the Turkish Version of Cognitive Triad Inventory for Adults will be higher than the scores that individuals who are insecurely attached to their pet will receive from the Turkish Version of Cognitive Triad Inventory for Adults. It is expected that the scores that individuals who are securely attached to their parents will receive from the Turkish Version of Cognitive Triad Inventory for Adults will be higher than the scores that individuals who are insecurely attached to their parents will receive from the Turkish Version of Cognitive Triad Inventory for Adults. It is also estimated that the positive triad will be mainly predicted to the attachment style of pets in stead of the attachment style of parents.

3. Individuals who are insequrely attached to their parents and raised in a family which have a pet when they are between 5 and 11, will have high positive cognitive triad compared with those who do not.

q6: No blinding is involved in this study.

registration_responses.q13: The main sample of the study will consists of minimum 206 participants who are adult and have pet will be selected randomly. The interaction effect of the first independent variable based on the attachement style of pets (high secure attachment-low secure attachment) and the second independent variable based on the attachment style of parents (high secure attachment-low secure attachment) on the cognitive triad is df = 2 and the total number of groups are (2 × 2) n = 4.
registration_responses.q14: It is used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. The total number of participants required for the possibility of rejecting the H0 hypothesis correctly by 95% was determined as minimum 206 by G*Power analysis.

registration_responses.q8.question: It will be measured the relationship between the attachment styles of individuals to their pets and parents, and the cognitive triad. The participants who are over their 28 and have pet will be reached randomly. In the Informed Consent Form which was prepared by researcher, it was stated that the purpose of the research.  The answers will be kept confidential and used only for scientific purposes. The participation will be based on volunteering, and the approvals of the participants will be obtained. The scales will be given to participants via Qualtrics. IBM SPSS 22.0 version will be used to analyze the collected data. Percentage, mean, standard deviation, frequency, correlation analysis, two-way ANOVA and regression analyzes will be used. Data on incomplete scales will not be included in the analyzes.

registration_responses.q17.question:
1. The Turkish Version of Lexington Attachment to Pets Scale consists of a 4 Likert-type and 23-item. It has a 3-factor; the connection to the pet (My pet understands when I feel bad.), assuming the friendship of pet equal to people (My pet is more valuable to me than any friend), and lastly assuming the rights of animals equal to people (Pets, like all family members, have the same rights and privileges.). General attachment factor is represented by items 10, 11, 12, 13, 15, 17, 18, 19, 21, 22 and 23; human replacement factor is represented by items 1, 2, 4, 5, 6, 7 and 9; animal rights factor is represented by items 3, 8, 14, 16 and 20. The reliability of the scale was tested with the Cronbach Alpha coefficient. There was evidence of the reliability of the Turkish form in the factors of total (.91), human replacement (.78), animal rights (.70) and general attachment (.86). The increase in the total score obtained from the scale indicates an increase in the level of attachment to the animal. 

2. Three Dimensional Attachment Styles Scale was developed by Erzen (2015) aims to measure secure, avoided and anxious attachment styles. The scale consists of 18 items evaluated in the Likert-type 5. .72 for content validity were calculated. According to exploratory factor analysis, secure attachment factor is represented by items 4, 7, 10, 13, 16 (I get along well with my parents (mother, father or someone else taking care of me).), avoided attachment factor is represented by items 1, 3, 5, 9, 12, 15 (People who I know are not as valuable as me.), and anxious attachment factor is represented by items 2, 6, 8, 11, 14, 17 (I stay away from people because they can make me suffer). According to the factors of the scale, the internal consistency coefficient was found to be .69 for secure attachment style, .80 for avoided attachment style and .71 for anxious attachment style. Low scores from the scale indicate insecure attachment, and high scores indicate secure attachment to the parents.

3. Cognitive Triad Inventory is composed of items that measure both positive and negative cognitions of individuals. Self-perception factor is represented by items 6, 9, 11, 15, 16, 19, 26, 28, 32, 36 (I can do many things well), world perception factor is represented by items 5, 10, 13, 17, 21, 25, 29, 31, 33, 35 (The world is a very hostile place.), and future perception factor is represented by items 3, 8, 12, 18, 20, 23, 24, 27, 30, 34. (Nothing I expect from the future.). In the form, which is prepared in 7-point Likert type, one of the options is marked between "I disagree" (1 point) and "I fully agree" (7 points) for each item. While the items are scored, all of the positive items are reversed and the low scores from the scale reflect the positive cognitive triad, and the high scores reflect the negative cognitive triad. The Cronbach Alpha reliability coefficient for the whole scale was reported as .91, .85 for self-perception, .72 for world perception, and .87 for future perception.
